awd_titl_txt: East Coast Oceanographic Consortium Proposal to Operate Regional Class Research Vessel (RCRV) #2
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal is for the ship operator selection of RCRV # 2.  The monetary value of the proposal has no relation to the first year operational costs, and the selection process does not entitle the awardee to any ship operation funds until transition to operations has occurred.  The awardee will enter into a contract with OSU under the MREFC phase of construction and delivery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. government’s investment in ocean observation has significantly impacted our daily lives. Today’s weather forecasts, including those on your smartphone, are more accurate and can predict further into the future than just a few years ago—thanks to expanded ocean monitoring systems and infrastructure. New research ships are critical for the future of US leadership in ocean science and related industries (e.g., fisheries and advanced technology, such as deep-sea robotics), as the ocean is a vast expanse covering 71% of the Earth’s surface. Ocean access for US scientists and students is primarily via the Academic Research Fleet (ARF). The National Science Foundation’s investment in a new Academic Research Fleet for regional ocean access is underway. The Regional Class Research Vessel (RCRV), RCRV #2 – R/V Narragansett Dawn, represents federal investment to ensure access to economically valuable ocean and coastal waters off the East Coast of the United States. This NSF-supported investment in ship-based ocean infrastructure not only enhances ocean research, but also enables important advances in ocean technology, STEM education and teacher training, and marine workforce development.

NSF’s investment in ocean observing infrastructure, including the ARF and regional class research vessels, enables critical monitoring of ocean health. This includes tracking harmful algal blooms, management of valuable fisheries, planning for extreme weather, mapping the seafloor, and assessing ocean biodiversity. With improved NSF-funded ship-based ocean observations, communities are better informed, resulting in improved decision-making and planning, and, ultimately, saving money for taxpayers, the government, and partners. Research vessels also provide hands-on learning experiences for American students and professionals, building a skilled, ocean-literate workforce for the 21st century. NSF is committed to ensuring that the US leads the world in ocean infrastructure and workforce development, supporting the security of our homeland and sustainability of its resources.

Over the past several decades, the United States has developed its maritime workforce, known as the blue workforce, across the country. Many regions, especially along the East Coast, have a strong interest in marine science and ocean engineering. Federal investment in the Regional Class Research Vessels (RCRV) will ensure continued widespread access to advanced research vessels, submersibles, and related facilities that are crucial for robust research and educational programs in ocean sciences that will strengthen the blue workforce. The R/V Narragansett Dawn, when completed, will be used by the ocean-going science and technology communities to carry out a broad range of oceanographic research over the next 40 years. This investment will impact our understanding of the oceans, marine food production, and national security, along with supporting a range of educational activities. The R/V Narragansett Dawn will facilitate the needs of academic oceanographic programs, thereby continuing and enhancing the excellence of the nation's ocean research and education, as well as workforce training. The project is providing training to mariners and support staff on ship construction and cutting-edge marine technology. Educational events and activities have already engaged K-12 students and teachers in Rhode Island, including those from historically marginalized and underrepresented communities. The activities associated with the Regional Class Research Vessel R/V Narragansett Dawn will continue to spark interest and educational engagement in maritime fields for years to come.
